translated: Jātaka🔽The Collection of Middle-Length Discourses
The Chapter on Bad Sons
The Suvaṇṇakakkata Jātaka🔽“The peacock, with his long eyes on his tail feathers,
Standing on one leg, with no feathers, no hair,
I’m overcome by him, I weep pitifully,

original: Hare sakhā kissa nu maṁ jahāsi”.
analyzed: hare sakhā kissa nu mama jahāsi
translated: Hare, friend, why do you abandon me?”
He saw the snake, with his great hood,
The snake-king in the middle of the kakkaṭa,
The friend protecting his friend,
The kakkaṭa grabbed the snake.
“Not a crow, nor a black snake,
The kakkaṭa, seeking food, would not let go;
I ask you, with your long eyes on your tail feathers,
For what reason are we both grabbed?”
“This man is my benefactor,
Who, having grabbed me, leads me to his home;
If he dies, my suffering will be great,

original: Ahañca eso ca ubho na homa.
analyzed: ahan ca eso ca ubhau na
translated: And neither he nor I will be here.
And seeing my body growing fat,
All people would want to harm me;
Delicious, fat, and tender flesh,
Even crows, seeing me, would harass me.”
“If I have both of you in my power,
I will rise up and crush the man;
But quickly let go of the crow,

analyzed: pure visam gāḍham upeti mat ca
translated: Before the poison spreads through his body.”
“I will let go of the snake, but not yet the crow;
The crow is still my companion;
But when I see the man well and healthy,
I will let go of the crow just as I did the snake.”
“The crow at that time was Devadatta,
The black snake was Māra,
The crow-keeper was Ānanda,

analyzed: aham tadā brāhmaṇaḥ homi satthā ati
translated: And I myself was the brahmin teacher.”
The Suvannaka Kakkata Jātaka is finished.
